just a buster sword from FF7 that cloud used. easy print. print with supports.  
1st uplaod!
made with solidworks
This is a full print for a single color. The sizes are roughly based off of the spare parts from Erik's upload: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:770

These print out great at .1-.15 layer thickness. I used .1mm with a feedrate/Travel feedrate of 30/45, and 66% fill. The print took me about an hour for one city, 30 min for a settlement, and 15 min for a road. I would guess at the settings I showed around 9 or so hours of print time. For those who care.
Roads are 25x5.5x5.5mm
Cities are 22.5x11.5x15mm roof is 90deg and side of roof is 5mm tall and 11.5mm long
Settlements are 10.25x14.5x8.5 the sides of the roof are 8mm and come out to just under 80deg angle. Link to my solid works file(2010 Premium): http://www.randomike.com/download/settlers1person.SLDPRT

comments.author: McMaster

description.text:
I've had a multitude of little issues with my late 2013 Simple's extruder and decided it needed some work... My filament would randomly walk out the side of the hobbed pulley, even when not jamming. I discovered 2 problems:

  • The filament had no guide on the way into the pulley. This would allow it to enter from an angle, and aide in the filament walking. For this, I took the design of the middle wooden piece of the extruder "housing" and I extended the top and added a guide that would only allow the filament to enter the pulley straight.

  • The bearing holding the filament to the pulley is fairly narrow, but was held by an extremely flimsy assembly of 3 wooden pieces glued together. If this wasn't glued perfectly straight, the bearing wouldn't be straight (parallel) to the pulley. Also, the sides of the wooden bearing holder were flat, so you could jam the bearing if you weren't tight enough. Not straight + not tight = not good.

You'll have to get into your extruder a bit to install these items, but I guarantee they're worth it! All instructions from the view in the picture looking at the pulley. First is the bearing pivot:

  • Remove the nut and bolt holding the tension on the extruder bearing (silver, full right).

  • Remove the upper right stepper motor/extruder bearing screw (silver).

  • Transfer the bearing, it's screw, and the pivot spacer to the new bearing pivot. I had to push a bit to get my bearing to "click" into the new bearing pivot, but it should easily sandwich between the shoulders to hold the inner bearing race.

  • Re-install reversing steps 2 & 1. Check for free movement.
    • The middle slat with the guide now needs to be installed:

  • Remove screws holding the hot end in place (black socket heads).

  • Remove the two left screws for the stepper motor (silver screws).

  • Lightly loosen the right stepper motor screws perhaps 1-2 turns - you don't have to take it all apart unless you want to!

  • There will be nothing holding in the middle wooden slat, so just push it to the left.

  • Put new middle slat in place & reverse instructions to reassemble.
    • Please keep in mind that the plastic guide tube for the filament below the extruder pulley needs to be against the hot end for the best guiding. Leave the stepper bolts slightly loose while you re-install the hot end, pushing the plastic tube up as you put the hot end in place. Make sure everything is as tight as it had been, and you set your spring tension for the extruder bearing pivot to a reasonable amount (you may have to play with this to get it perfect).

comments.text: Note: This is still working excellently after these 6 months. I've had a hot end die on me (unrelated), but these parts are still going strong.
comments.author: 8Complex

comments.text: Did you print these parts with PLA or ABS? How have they held up?
comments.author: AOcolossus

comments.text:
I printed these in the standard PLA without a heated bed. They've held up extremely well, I don't see any signs of wear.
With the one slat sandwiched between the other wooden pieces, I don't expect that any warping would really be a problem, although printing upright (as the STL is oriented) really shouldn't cause any warping to begin with.
The bearing arm is holding up really well, too, especially considering it is always under the spring pressure. I may go back and add a little extension for a thumb-lift point, but I've had so few occasions when I needed to pull the filament out, I'm not sure it is worth it.
comments.author: AOcolossus

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cmgBhMTMsAP

12mm X 12mm X 2mm Tiles to test out my dual extruder conversion of my Airwolf 3DXL.  
"Progress" from left to right.  Lesson 1: un-check retract only when crossing perimeters.  
Still have some work to get my 2nd extruder to work as well as the original one,  had a stripped filament that was messing things up and the feed rate is not right.  
I'm still trying to figure out how to update my Repetier Firmware to get the offset recognized.  For now I'm using slic3r to do the offset, but I know that's a band aid approach.  I also need to dig around in the firmware to adjust my 2nd extruder feed rate.  My home made hobbed bolt bust be off a little because not enough is coming out.

title: MendelMax Laser Cut LM8UU Y Axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A laser cut Y axis for the MendelMax, but using LM8UU bearings. This particular Y table has support for an endstop screw and comes with a belt fix. I also attached the AutoDesk Inventor sources, in case someone's interested (they're a bit messy). WARNING: just made this work in progress as I've realized that, if you plan to use the "standard" heated PCB, that is 214x214mm, it will not fit in the carriage. Fix is on the way ...

• cut out of 6mm plywood, you need every part twice
  • put in the LM8UU's using zip ties, make sure you fit the bearings on the correct side.
  • put the whole thing together - should be straight forward using M5x12mm screws. The endstop hole is the only one for an M4 screw.

comments.text: What needs to be done to enable the use of a 214 x 214 heated pcb?

title: Camera Mount for the Foldable Micro H-Quadcopter

description.text:
Update: 4/21/2014
I uploaded "RevB" Which changes to the way the camera mounts to the block. I have not had the chance to print one yet, but once I do, I will post a photo. The major change is the camera now mounts behind the front surface of the mount with a small hole for the lens. The lens should land just about flush with the front surface. Original Description:
This is a camera mount for the Foldable Micro H-Quadcopter. This mounts on the underside of the camera plate which still allows for the Go-Pro or Mobius to be mounted on the upper side. The cutouts are to accomidate the connectors and larger parts on the SecurityCamera2000 Sony 600TVL Board camera. I am not 100% satisfied with this design, so I may improve it. The biggest part that I don't like is that the camera sticks way out in front which is in a bad place if you happen to crash. I haven't tested FPV yet, but it may also be in the shot of the gopro/mobius. Anyhow I present it here in hopes others will get some use out of it and maybe improve it in ways I haven't thought of.
3D print, and mount per photo.

comments.text:
I have my frame done but don't have a mobius yet. Wouldn't the mobius fit between the top mount frame and the middle frame where controller sits? And put the FPV cam on top? I was debating doing what you're doing but I couldn't think of a good way to do it without raising the standoffs past 20mm..
But i've been looking at the dimensions of the Mobius and from what I've measured on the calipers on the frame and the specs of the mobius, it should slide right in there.
comments.author: OsiViper

comments.text: You could put the flight cam on top.  I am pretty sure the mobius will fit where you described, however I don't own a mobius to tell for sure.
comments.author: OsiViper

comments.text: Looks good but I agree that it sticks out too far. I designed the top plate for mounting smaller live view cams underneath. Preferably cams that can be simply zip-tied in place.

remixed_from.author: adafruit
remixed_from.title: Adafruit Pi Box - Enclosure for Raspberry PiÂ® Computers

description.text:
I really liked the Adafruit Pi case so I made my own version. It will stack tightly and has both a full legnth top and a shorter top for use with the slice of pi board by Ciseco http://goo.gl/566lk This version is drawn from scratch in draftsight rather that from the Adafruit file here (I actually didnt see it on thingiverse until after finishing the basic layout so figured I may as well finish it). The etched logos in the photos are all from thenounproject.com with the exception of the Raspberry Pi Logo. Its designed to be cut from 3mm material. Personally i like it in wood :) Prototyped at the wonderful Nottingham Hackspace http://nottinghack.org.uk/ Build photos here http://goo.gl/oEH5c Icons
http://thenounproject.com/noun/ethernet/#icon-No456
http://thenounproject.com/noun/power/#icon-No94
http://thenounproject.com/noun/usb/#icon-No140
http://thenounproject.com/noun/sd-card/#icon-No1073
http://thenounproject.com/noun/computer/#icon-No115
http://thenounproject.com/noun/speaker/#icon-No1898
http://thenounproject.com/noun/television/#icon-No416 Attached zip has icons flipped for etching in acrylic

Update - Added A4 version for cutting two cases from a single A4 sheet of acrylic Ive included three versions. One normal for cutting in 3mm acrylic, one reversed for cutting in plywood (etches need to on the outside with wood and inside on acrylic) and a final one for cutting 2x pi cases from a single sheet of a4. Instructions Complete assembly instructions available at Adafruit:
wiki.ladyada.net/products/pi-box Extra tips/things to consider Make sure you clip the usb side end plate first and make sure the top side of the end plate is all the way over the hooks before fixing the bottom hooks on.
Acrylic is hard but also brittle, it's a tight fit so if its not on right and you force it the clips could snap off.
Also it comes with two top plates, a full size and half size one for using the gpio Enjoy

description.text: This is designed to replace the mount/holder that comprises the upper portion of a Belkin TuneDock adapter. An iPhone 5S within a fairly thin M4 Q-card case fits snugly in this holder. The outside dimensions of the iPhone with its case are: 60.9mm wide and 12.25mm thick

1 Print the two parts and then glue them together.
  • Unscrew the bolt in your TuneDock adapter and replace the existing iPhone mount with this one.
  • Reinstall the bolt
